model.description:
The return values of smartctl are defined by a bitmask.  
If all is well with the disk, the return value (exit status) of smartctl is 0 (all bits turned off). If a problem occurs, or an error, potential error, or fault is detected, then a non-zero status is returned.  
In this case, the eight different bits in the return value have the following meanings for ATA disks; some of these values may also be returned for SCSI disks.

Bit 0:  
Command line did not parse.

Bit 1:  
Device open failed, device did not return an IDENTIFY DEVICE structure, or device is in a low-power mode (see '-n' option above).

Bit 2:  
Some SMART or other ATA command to the disk failed, or there was a checksum error in a SMART data structure (see '-b' option above).

Bit 3:  
SMART status check returned "DISK FAILING".

Bit 4:  
We found prefail Attributes <= threshold.

Bit 5:  
SMART status check returned "DISK OK" but we found that some (usage or prefail) Attributes have been <= threshold at some time in the past.

Bit 6:  
The device error log contains records of errors.

Bit 7:  
The device self-test log contains records of errors. [ATA only] Failed self-tests outdated by a newer successful extended self-test are ignored.
model.title: SmartCtl Exit Bits

list.expr:
sum(smartctl_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"})
by(smartctl_version, svn_revision, build_info) 
    unless 
(
    sum(
        # If there are NaNs we get a version change, fix this by looking at the most recent one if there is nan.
        # Also set the step to min $__interval, in metrisql this is 1i (to get an instant anotation and not range anotation)
        keep_last_value(
        #last_over_time(
            smartctl_version{job=~"$job", instance=~"$instance"} offset 1i
        )
    ) 
    by(smartctl_version, svn_revision, build_info)
)
list.name: smartctl version

Also other devices that existed for this time range (more info on the panels below)

targets.expr:
# Use device="${nvme_serial:text}" to get the device name.
max(smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial", instance=~"$instance"}) by(serial_number, model_name)

#(smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial", instance=~"$instance"} default 0) == 0
vector(0) unless on() smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial", instance=~"$instance"}

panels.description: SMART overall-health self-assessment test result
Can help detect if there where some physical disk changes
panels.title: Historical Device uses for this serial number

targets.expr:
# NOTE: For now we are listing serial numbers and joining them with the metric we want from "smartctl_device", 
#  if a device doesn't have a serial number this repeat will not work, redoit.

max(smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial",instance=~"$instance"}
  * on(device,instance) group_right(model_name,serial_number)
  smartctl_device_bytes_written{instance=~"$instance"}) without(device)

# NOTE: For now we are listing serial numbers and joining them with the metric we want from "smartctl_device", 
#  if a device doesn't have a serial number this repeat will not work, redoit.

max(smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial",instance=~"$instance"}
  * on(device,instance) group_right(model_name,serial_number)
  smartctl_device_bytes_read{instance=~"$instance"}) without(device)

# NOTE: For now we are listing serial numbers and joining them with the metric we want from "smartctl_device", 
#  if a device doesn't have a serial number this repeat will not work, redoit.

max(smartctl_device{serial_number="$nvme_serial",instance=~"$instance"}
  * on(device,instance) group_right(model_name,serial_number)
  smartctl_device_capacity_bytes{instance=~"$instance"}) without(device)

panels.description:
Available Spare: Normalized percentage (0 to 100%) of the remaining spare capacity available

Spare Threshold: When the Available Spare falls below the threshold indicated in this field, an asynchronous event completion may occur. The value is indicated as a normalized percentage (0 to 100%)
panels.title: Drive Spare

panels.description:
Percentage Used (PUSED): Contains a vendor specific estimate of the percentage of NVM subsystem
life used based on the actual usage and the manufacturer’s prediction of NVM life.  

A value of 100 indicates that the estimated endurance of the NVM in the NVM subsystem has been consumed, but may not indicate an NVM subsystem failure. The value is allowed to exceed 100. Percentages greater than 254 shall be represented as 255. This value shall be updated once per power-on hour (when the controller is not in a sleep state).   

Refer to the JEDEC JESD218B-02 standard for SSD device life and endurance measurement
techniques.
panels.title: Percentage Used

panels.description:
**Critical Warning**: This field indicates critical warnings for the state of the controller. Each bit corresponds to a critical warning type; multiple bits may be set. If a bit is cleared to ‘0’, then that critical warning does not apply. Critical warnings may result in an asynchronous event notification to the host. Bits in this field represent the state at the time the Get Log Page command is processed and may not reflect the state at the time a related asynchronous event notification, if any, occurs or occurred. https://nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-Base-Specification-Revision-2.1-2024.08.05-Ratified.pdf#%5B%7B%22num%22%3A871%2C%22gen%22%3A0%7D%2C%7B%22name%22%3A%22XYZ%22%7D%2C75%2C627%2C0%5D **Bit Definition** | Bits | Description |------------|--| |7:6| Reserved | |5| Persistent Memory Region Read-Only (PMRRO): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then the Persistent Memory Region has become read-only or unreliable (refer to section 8.2.4). https://nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-Base-Specification-Revision-2.1-2024.08.05-Ratified.pdf#%5B%7B%22num%22%3A1486%2C%22gen%22%3A0%7D%2C%7B%22name%22%3A%22XYZ%22%7D%2C69%2C250%2C0%5D | |4| Volatile Memory Backup Failed (VMBF): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then the volatile memory backup device has failed. This field is only valid if the controller has a volatile memory backup solution.| |3| All Media Read-Only (AMRO): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then all of the media has been placed in read only mode. The controller shall not set this bit to '1' if the read-only condition on the media is a result of a change in the write protection state of a namespace (refer to section 8.1.16.1). https://nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-Base-Specification-Revision-2.1-2024.08.05-Ratified.pdf#%5B%7B%22num%22%3A1387%2C%22gen%22%3A0%7D%2C%7B%22name%22%3A%22XYZ%22%7D%2C69%2C193%2C0%5D | |2| NVM Subsystem Degraded Reliability (NDR): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then the NVM subsystem reliability has been degraded due to significant media related errors or any internal error that degrades NVM subsystem reliability. | |1| Temperature Threshold Condition (TTC): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then a temperature is:
a) greater than or equal to an over temperature threshold; or
b) less than or equal to an under temperature threshold,
(refer to section 5.1.25.1.3). https://nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-Base-Specification-Revision-2.1-2024.08.05-Ratified.pdf#%5B%7B%22num%22%3A1076%2C%22gen%22%3A0%7D%2C%7B%22name%22%3A%22XYZ%22%7D%2C69%2C193%2C0%5D | |0| Available Spare Capacity Below Threshold (ASCBT): If this bit is set to ‘1’, then the available spare capacity has fallen below the threshold. |
panels.title: Device Critical warning bits

panels.description: **Number of Error Information Log Entries** (NEILE): Contains the number of Error Information Log Entries over the life of the controller.
panels.title: NVME Error Information Log Entries

panels.description:
Media and Data Integrity Errors (MDIE): Contains the number of occurrences where the controller detected an unrecovered data integrity error. 

Errors such as uncorrectable ECC, CRC checksum failure, or LBA tag mismatch are included in this field. Errors introduced as a result of a Write Uncorrectable command (refer to the NVM Command Set Specification) may or may not be included in this field.
panels.title: NVME Media Errors

panels.description:
##### SMART 169: Remaining Lifetime Percentage (Western Digital)

This attribute measures the approximate life left from a combination of program-erase cycles and available reserve blocks of the device. A brand new SSD will report a value of “100” for the Normalized value and decrease down to “0” as the drive is used.

##### SMART 202: Percentage of Lifetime Remaining (Crucial)

Read [crucial.com SMART Data](https://www.crucial.com/support/articles-faq-ssd/ssds-and-smart-data)

This can mean Lifetime Remaining or Lifetime Used, most of the time the value of the smart data will be **Remaining life**, and the raw value, used life.

##### SMART 231: Life Left (Seagate)

This attribute indicates the approximate SSD life left, in terms of program/erase cycles or available reserved blocks. A brand new SSD has a normalized value of “100” and decreases from there with a threshold value at “10” indicating a need for replacement. A value of “0” may mean that the drive is operating in read-only mode.
panels.title: SSD Lifetime %

panels.description: May be wrong for ATAs (excessive numbers)

Based on https://www.backblaze.com/blog/hard-drive-smart-stats/

If you see some increasing RED colors here,danger. It may still last a long time depending if Power On Hours < 4 years.  
If the colors are not red, beware.

These are RAW values.
panels.title: Important SMART RAW metrics

panels.description:
Execute: `smartctl.exe --log=error --log=selftest {device}` (as admin)    
On the instance console to see more details.

targets.legendFormat: ATA Self test {{self_test_log_type}} Error log count

panels.title: ATA SMART Error Log Count

panels.description:
Short flags:  
 ||||||_ K auto-keep   
 |||||__ C event count  
 ||||___ R error rate  
 |||____ S speed/performance  
 ||_____ O updated online  
 |______ P prefailure warning  

Wikipedia:  
[Wikipedia S.M.A.R.T Attributes](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-Monitoring,_Analysis_and_Reporting_Technology#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes)

Blackblaze on ATA SSDs  
[Blackblaze SSD SMART article](https://www.backblaze.com/blog/making-sense-of-ssd-smart-stats/)

For Micron Smart SSD read:  
[crucial.com Official smart data](https://www.crucial.com/support/articles-faq-ssd/ssds-and-smart-data)

SSD SMART Comparison table from Blackblaze:  
[PDF Table](https://f001.backblazeb2.com/file/Backblaze_Blog/SSD+SMART+Stats+Comparison+Table.pdf)

panels.description:
The return values of smartctl are defined by a bitmask.  
If all is well with the disk, the return value (exit status) of smartctl is 0 (all bits turned off). If a problem occurs, or an error, potential error, or fault is detected, then a non-zero status is returned.  
In this case, the eight different bits in the return value have the following meanings for ATA disks; some of these values may also be returned for SCSI disks.

Bit 0:  
Command line did not parse.

Bit 1:  
Device open failed, device did not return an IDENTIFY DEVICE structure, or device is in a low-power mode (see '-n' option above).

Bit 2:  
Some SMART or other ATA command to the disk failed, or there was a checksum error in a SMART data structure (see '-b' option above).

Bit 3:  
SMART status check returned "DISK FAILING".

Bit 4:  
We found prefail Attributes <= threshold.

Bit 5:  
SMART status check returned "DISK OK" but we found that some (usage or prefail) Attributes have been <= threshold at some time in the past.

Bit 6:  
The device error log contains records of errors.

Bit 7:
